Award.AwardTitle: Vital Voices: Linking Language and Wellbeing at the International Conference on Language Documentation and Conservation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
"Wellbeing" is a state of the body and mind that encompasses the presence of positive moods and emotions, life satisfaction, fulfillment and positive functioning, and the absence of negative emotions like anxiety. Public health experts, policymakers and economists are coming to recognize the implications of wellbeing for society as a whole, as well as individuals, thanks to a growing set of results from cross-sectional, longitudinal and experimental studies, including those noted by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Increasingly, researchers in several fields have noted a positive correlation between language maintenance and wellbeing in endangered language communities. While the nature of the connection between language and wellbeing remains the subject of much debate, the existence of a connection is not entirely unexpected, given the range of outcomes associated with wellbeing. In addition, languages encode knowledge systems, so language loss represents not only the loss of a communicative system, but also the loss of traditional knowledge systems. Importantly, traditional knowledge systems encode cultural practices related to well-being. Understanding the connections between language and wellbeing will potentially have implications for public health and policy and beyond, but also for language researchers, since traditional knowledge systems are among the most threatened domains of endangered language. Knowledge of esoteric domains such botanical classification and traditional medicines is forgotten well before basic vocabulary and language structure. Hence, these areas of traditional knowledge are precisely the areas which need to be prioritized by language documenters.

This project will bring together leading scholars from across the world to explore connections between language and wellbeing as part of the 2017 International Conference on Language Documentation and Conservation (ICLDC). Since its inception in 2009, ICLDC has become the flagship venue driving scholarship in the documentation, maintenance and revitalization of endangered and other languages. Participants include undergraduate students, graduate students and faculty from linguistics, anthropology, biology and other academic disciplines. ICLDC has also included a large number of citizen scientists from historically underrepresented groups in the sciences, such as Native Americans, Native Alaskans, Native Hawaiians and other Pacific Islanders, offering opportunities for broadening participation in the language sciences as one of the broader impacts of this conference.

ICLDC offers its highly diverse audience opportunities for informal science education and training that includes new methodologies and best practices in cutting edge language documentation and that crosses traditional disciplinary boundaries. In addition, this conference serves as one of the foremost venues for the dissemination of research findings in language documentation and conservation and related disciplines.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 5th International Conference on Language Documentation & Conservation (ICLDC) was held at the University of Hawai'i at Manoa, March 2-5, 2017. The conference theme "Vital Voices: Linking Language and Wellbeing" highlighted the link between linguistic and cultural preservation on the one hand, and all aspects of personal and community wellbeing on the other hand.

ICLDC5 was once again very popular, with over 480 registrants, including regular attendees, presenters, Workshop/Talk Story presenters, and volunteers. Participants attended from 31 countries: Albania, Argentina, Australia, Azerbaijan, Cameroon, Canada, China, Finland, France, French Polynesia, Germany, Italy, Japan, Kazakhstan, Mexico, Netherlands, New Zealand, Nicaragua, Nigeria, Pakistan, Papua New Guinea, Philippines, Poland, Russia, Singapore, South Korea, Switzerland, Taiwan, Thailand, Trinidad and Tobago, United Kingdom, and the United States.

The program committee reviewed close to 250 abstracts and ultimately selected 150 abstracts for presentation. These presentations and posters represented almost 100 languages worldwide.

The conference had many unique features:

  • Two plenary presentations: Dr. Alice Taff (University of Alaska Southeast) I Gu.aa Yáx X'wán: Be of Good Courage; and Dr. Richard Oster (University of Alberta) & Rick Lightning (Ermineskin Cree Nation) Can Language and Cultural Continuity Protect Against Diabetes in First Nations Communities?
  • Six special Workshops: Gretchen McCulloch (All Things Linguistic), Wikipedia Edit-A-Thon; Evan Gardner and Susanna Ciotti, Where Are Your Keys?; Ruth Rouvier (UC Berkeley), Joanne Kemp-Philo (Head Start National Center), Tracy Hirata-Edds (U Kansas), Documentation, Revitalization, and Benefits for Young Learners and Their Communities; Aliana Parker and Suzanne Gessner (First People's Cultural Council), Our Language is Our Health: Connecting Language Revitalization to Health Outcomes for Indigenous Communities; Shoichi Iwasaki, William O'Grady, Sejung Yang (U Hawaii Manoa), Changyong Yang (Jeju National University), Hiroyuki Nakama (Prefectural Museum, Japan), Masahiro Yamada (Ritsumeikan University), Yukinori Takubo (Kyoto University), Mutual Intelligibility and Mutual Respect: The effect of language devaluation on self-esteem; Cikgaq-Irasema Ortega (U Alaska Anchorage), Flora Ayuluk, Lillian Olson, Lisa Unin (Chevak Immersion School, Alaska), Science, Technology, Engineering, Arts, and Mathematics (STEAM) Curriculum as a Lens for Language and Culture Revitalization in Alaska.
  • Eight Talk Story Roundtable discussion sessions: Susan Penfield, Interdisciplinarity in Language & Wellness: How To Do It? How to Fund It?; Richard Oster (U Alberta) and Rick Lightning (Ermineskin Cree Nation), Our Histories Flow Through Our Blood: Diabetes in Indigenous Communities; Michael Walsh, Language is Like Food; Keren Rice (U Toronto) and Mary Linn (Smithsonian Center for Folklife and Cultural Heritage), Language Surveys and Wellbeing; Candance Kaleimamoowahinekapu Galla (U British Columbia) and Alanaise Goodwill (U British Columbia), Asserting Wellbeing Through Reclamation and Revitalization of Our Indigenous Languages; Wesley Leonard (UC Riverside) and Daisy Rosenblum (U British Columbia), Decolonizing Indigenous Language Pedagogies: Embodied Approaches to Teaching and Learning; Lgeik'i Heather Powell, Naakil.aan Hans Chester, Seigoot Jessica Chester (SEAlaska), Sharing and Designing Collaborative Outreach Projects for Language and Community Wellness; Lolena Nichols, Larry Kimura, Keiki Kawai'ae'a, Kanani Kawai'ae'a, Alohalani Housman, Kau'i Kaian (U Hawaii), The Punana Leo Experience: Returning Hawaiian to the Children While Impacting the Lives of New and Native Speakers Alike.

The conference focus on language and wellbeing is transformational for the field of language documentation and conservation, demonstrating the potential for indigenous language research efforts to have a tangible effect on the health of their speakers. Research presented at the ICLDC has already led to many new developments in this area and to new research initiatives. 

The conference was held in conjunction with two complementary programs. The Hilo Field Study, in which participants visit the Hawaiian immersion K-12 and University programs on the Big Island of Hawaii was held in the 3 days before the ICLDC. The ComputEL conference, dedicated to supporting technology for indigenous and endangered languages, was held in the few days after the ICLDC.

Recordings of all the talks, as well as any slides, papers, handouts or posters associated with the presentations and the Workshops at the ICLDC have been deposited in ScholarSpace, the UH Manoa institutional repository. They are freely downloadable at https://hdl.handle.net/10125/45840.
